importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of the government shutdown and the impending food stamp benefits lapse in November.
The start date of the federal government shutdown, which triggered the funding crisis for food stamp and WIC programs.
The date when the USDA informed states that full food stamp benefits would be unavailable in November if funding continues to lapse.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The critical two-week period leading up to November 1, when SNAP benefits are expected to run out due to lack of federal funding.

keyTakeAways: Approximately 42 million Americans are at risk of losing access to food stamp benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has confirmed that the food stamp program will deplete its funds in two weeks, with no immediate contingency funds to cover the full November benefit payment.
The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP benefits, unlike with other programs, and has instead blamed Democrats for political obstruction.
A $6 billion contingency fund exists, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
17 states have halted new food stamp applications due to the inability to issue partial payments for both October and November.
The Trump administration diverted $300 million in tariff revenue to keep WIC operational, but that same revenue is insufficient for SNAP.
Food stamp benefits are especially critical during the Thanksgiving season, and food pantries are already overstretched.
Democrats and advocacy groups argue that the administration must act urgently to protect vulnerable families, citing past precedent where similar programs were sustained through emergency measures.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The official name of the U.S. food stamp program that provides monthly benefits to low-income families.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SNAP is central to the article as it is at risk of shutting down in November due to federal funding shortfalls, directly affecting millions of vulnerable Americans.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal program providing food assistance to pregnant women, new mothers, and young children.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC was previously kept afloat through a $300 million tariff revenue diversion, highlighting that other nutrition programs are also under threat during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Agriculture Secretary who publicly criticized Democrats for political obstruction of funding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rollins is a key government official who directly addressed the funding crisis and attributed the shortfall to Democratic political behavior.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Governor of New York, who criticized the Trump administration's decision to halt benefits.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hochul represents a state-level response to the shutdown, arguing that the federal government must prioritize vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The current U.S. federal executive branch, which has been criticized for not funding SNAP benefits.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The administration is central to the conflict, as it has failed to provide funding for SNAP and instead blamed Democrats for political inaction.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. political party accused by the Trump administration of obstructing funding for food programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democrats argue that Republicans are responsible for the shutdown, and that the lack of bipartisan spending negotiations has led to the crisis.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal agency responsible for administering SNAP and WIC programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA is the primary body managing the food stamp and WIC programs and has issued warnings about funding depletion and payment delays.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body where Republicans and Democrats are in a standoff over federal spending.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The impasse in Congress is the root cause of the government shutdown, which has led to the funding crisis for food assistance programs.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN reporter who authored the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As a journalist, Luhby is responsible for reporting the story, and her byline identifies the source and credibility of the article.

namedEntities.name: Gina Plata-Nino
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Acting director of SNAP at the Food Research & Action Center, an advocacy group.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Plata-Nino emphasizes the human impact of the food stamp crisis, highlighting the need for urgent action during Thanksgiving.

namedEntities.name: Ty Jones Cox
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vice president of food assistance at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cox argues that households in need should not be sacrificed during the shutdown and calls for immediate intervention.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing access to food stamp benefits in November due to a federal government shutdown that has depleted the USDAâ€™s funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). Despite a $6 billion contingency fund, the projected $8 billion in November benefits cannot be covered. The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP, instead blaming Democrats for political obstruction, while states like New York have criticized the decision as harmful to vulnerable families. A similar funding crisis previously occurred in 2018, where a temporary provision allowed benefits to be paid after a lapse. This time, 17 states have halted new applications due to payment constraints, and while WIC was temporarily protected through a $300 million tariff revenue diversion, that same resource is insufficient for SNAP. Advocacy groups emphasize the urgency of the situation, particularly as Thanksgiving approaches, and call for immediate action to prevent widespread hunger among low-income households.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
